= left =

'''left''' is a DIL function that extracts the leftmost characters from a string.

== Syntax ==
 string left(string input, integer length)

== Parameters ==
; input : string
: The original string to be parsed
; length : integer
: The number of characters to extract from the left side of the string

== Return Value ==
; string
: Returns the left portion of the input string with the specified length. Returns '''null''' if:
* The input string is empty
* The length parameter is 0
* Either parameter is invalid

== Description ==
The '''left''' function extracts a specified number of characters from the beginning (left side) of a string. If the requested length is longer than the input string, the entire string is returned.

This function is commonly used for:
* String prefix matching
* Extracting substrings from the beginning of text
* Command parsing and abbreviation handling
* Text processing where only the beginning of a string is needed

== Examples ==
 // Basic usage
 result := left("shorten me", 5);        // Returns "short"

 // When length exceeds string length
 result := left("hi", 10);               // Returns "hi"

 // Empty string handling
 result := left("", 5);                  // Returns null

 // Zero length
 result := left("hello", 0);             // Returns null

 // Prefix matching for commands
 if (command == left("help", length(command))) {
    // Handle help command or abbreviations
 }

== Advanced Usage ==
The function is particularly useful for command abbreviation systems:

 // Check if input matches any command prefix
 commands := {"look", "get", "drop", "inventory"};
 i := 0;
 while (i < length(commands)) {
    if (input == left(commands.[i], length(input))) {
        // Found matching command
        exec(commands.[i] + " " + rest, self);
        break;
    }
    i := i + 1;
 }

== Notes ==
* The function allocates new memory for the returned string
* If the input string is shorter than the requested length, the entire string is returned
* Empty strings or zero length requests return null
* This is the counterpart to the [[right]] function
